title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Beef Fat Thing That Fixed My Winter Skin
body:
Okay so my face was just… done. It was a Tuesday, I think. Maybe Wednesday. The heater was blasting this dry, angry air and my skin felt like that crinkly paper they wrap around lightbulbs. You know the stuff. Tight. Itchy. Little flakes showing up around my eyebrows like dandruff but on my face, which is a whole new level of embarrassing. I’d tried everything. The fancy La Roche-Posay stuff from the pharmacy, the thick CeraVe tub, some Korean serum my friend swore by that cost like forty bucks for a tiny dropper. Nothing. It would feel okay for an hour and then back to desert mode. My hands were worse. Cracks by the thumbs. Looked like a map of the Grand Canyon. I was putting on this Neutrogena Norwegian Formula hand cream like five times a day and it just sat on top, all greasy, not helping.

Then I saw someone talking about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I was scrolling, probably avoiding work, and I just stopped. Beef. Fat. I pictured like, rubbing a steak on my cheeks. It sounded insane. But the person was so… normal about it. Not a weirdo. Just a person with skin that also hated winter. They mentioned this **lavender tallow balm** from some little shop. Said it was whipped, from grass-fed cows in France or something. I was skeptical. So skeptical. But my skin was so mad at me. I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I smell like a herb-crusted roast? I ordered it.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face (Seriously)

It arrived in this little jar. Simple. No crazy packaging. I opened it and just stared. It looked like… thick butter. Or whipped lard, which I guess is exactly what it is. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. Solid but soft. Kind of waxy? I brought it up to my nose. **Lavender tallow balm** smell. But not like a cheap air freshener. More like… real dried lavender from my grandma’s garden. Calming. Actually nice. Deep, herbal. Sleepy. I was in my kitchen, the overhead light was too bright, and my cat was yelling at me for dinner. I scooped a tiny bit out, rubbed it between my palms to warm it up. It melted. Like, instantly. Went from this solid balm to this silky oil. Weird.

I put it on my hands first. Because if I was gonna have a bad reaction, better my hands than my face. It soaked in. Fast. Like, really fast. No greasy film. My hands just felt… normal. Not slippery. Not coated. Just like skin, but not thirsty skin. Huh. Okay. So the next night, after washing my face, I tried a tiny dab on my cheeks and forehead. I braced for clogged pores, for a shiny greaseball face. It felt… rich. But again, it sank in. My face felt calm. Not instantly healed, but just… quiet. Like the angry tightness took a deep breath and sighed. I went to bed smelling like a peaceful field. Or a very fancy cow. I don’t know.

## What This Lavender Tallow Stuff Actually Does

Here’s the thing I read about later, which made the “beef fat” thing click. Our skin’s natural oil? Sebum? It’s got a similar fatty acid profile to tallow. So it’s like your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top as a barrier—it actually gets in there and says “hey, we’re cool, I got this.” It’s a **natural skincare** thing that’s been around forever, apparently. People used it for centuries. We just forgot because plastic bottles and chemical names are shinier.

This one’s whipped, so it’s this airy, luxurious texture. Not what you’d expect from the word “tallow.” It’s a **whipped tallow balm** made from grass-fed beef suet. From France. Sounds fancy, but it’s just rendered fat, whipped up. I use it as a night cream. The lavender scent is supposed to be calming, good for sleep. I’m not great at sleeping, my brain is always going, but I swear rubbing this on my face is part of my “shut down” routine now. The smell is timeless herbal. Not sweet. Just… grounding.

Oh, tangent—this reminds me of the hotel soap in this place I stayed in Portland. It was lavender too, but fake and screechy. This is the opposite of that. This is the real deal. Anyway.

For my **dry skin**, it’s been a game-changer. My face doesn’t feel like it’s going to crack when I smile in the morning. The flakiness around my brows? Gone in like, four days. I’ve been putting it on my elbows and those hand cracks too. It’s good for rough hands, for sensitive skin. I read it can help with things like psoriasis because it’s so nourishing and non-irritating. My skin just drinks it. It doesn’t clog my pores at all, which I was terrified about. It’s the opposite. It’s like it teaches my skin to chill out.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Weird Jar

I’m probably a month in now. I use it every night. Sometimes in the morning if it’s really brutal out. My skin is just… balanced. It’s not a miracle. I still get a spot if I eat too much sugar. But the overall dryness, the winter rage, is gone. My face feels resilient. My hands are actually presentable. No more bleeding cracks. I used to avoid handshakes. Now I’m like, whatever.

The jar is still half full. A little goes a long way. I got mine from this small Etsy shop—I’ll link it below maybe—because I’d rather buy from a person making small batches than some big factory. It feels more honest. The whole experience made me rethink **natural skincare**. Sometimes the simplest, oldest stuff is the answer. We overcomplicate everything.

I even got one for my mom. She has sensitive skin and everything makes her red. She called me last week and was like “what is this magic beef butter?” She loves it. She uses it on her cuticles.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already have a second jar in my cart for when this one runs out. I didn’t expect to be the person evangelizing about rendered cow fat, but here I am. It just works. I don’t know how else to say it. All those expensive, complicated products with twenty ingredients I can’t pronounce… they didn’t do what this one simple thing does.

If your skin is feeling tight, angry, flaky, or just generally pissed off at the weather, a **tallow balm for dry skin** might be worth a shot. Start with your hands if you’re weirded out. That’s what I did. The lavender scent is genuinely nice, especially for nighttime. It’s become my little ritual. Wash face, dab tallow, smell like a calm herb garden, go to bed. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. Because its fat is similar to our skin’s own oils, it absorbs deep and doesn’t just clog the surface. It’s like giving your skin food it actually recognizes. Weird but true.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. It’s non-comedogenic. It melts and sinks in instead of sitting on top. My pores have actually seemed clearer since using it, maybe because my skin isn’t freaking out and over-producing oil to compensate for being so dry.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Real dried lavender. Herbal, earthy, a little woody. Not sweet or perfume-y. It’s a calming, sleep-promoting kind of smell. Fades pretty quickly after you put it on, just leaves you with a subtle, relaxing vibe.

Anyway. If you're curious, it might be worth checking out. I'm just some person on the internet, but my face hasn't been this okay with winter in years.
